thread.title: Jeremy Corbyn to stage desperate fightback after Labour support PLUMMETS
thread.title_full: Jeremy Corbyn to stage desperate fightback after Labour support PLUMMETS

title: Jeremy Corbyn to stage desperate fightback after Labour support PLUMMETS
text:
Jeremy Corbyn to stage desperate fightback after Labour support PLUMMETS Jeremy Corbyn to stage desperate fightback after Labour support PLUMMETS JEREMY Corbyn will launch a desperate fightback today after his party saw support plummet in two by-elections in previously safe Labour seats. PUBLISHED: PUBLISHED: 22:01, Thu, Feb 23, 2017 GETTY Jeremy Corbyn will launch a fightback after Labour support has plummet in two by-elections 
With senior Labour figures questioning how long Mr Corbyn could hold on as leader, he will try to regain the initiative by brandishing his pro-EU credentials. 
Despite Labour facing annihilation in dozens of pro-Leave seats across the UK, Mr Corbyn will attack Theresa May ’s attempts to deliver Brexit as “false patriotism” and rebrand his party as “the voice of progressive Europe and European working people.” Related articles Stoke by-election: Nigel Farage will NOT be at vote amid Ukip scandal 
His intervention came after voters elected new MPs in two gruelling by-elections in Stoke Central, which has been held by Labour since 1950, and Copeland. 
Voters in Stoke Central and Copeland braved strong winds and rain lashing the country today to decide on who should replace two former moderate Labour MPs who quit because they believe their party cannot win with Mr Corbyn in charge. 
Stoke’s Tristram Hunt, once considered a future leader, left to become director of the V&A Museum in London, while Copeland’s Jamie Reed went to work for the nuclear industry in his former constituency. GETTY He will attack Theresa May's attempt to deliver Brexit as 'false patriotism' All the action from Stoke Central by-election Thu, February 23, 2017 Voting has begun in the Stoke-On-Trent Central by-election which was called after sitting Labour MP Tristram Hunt resigned from his seat to be a museum director. The seat has always been a Labour stronghold but will see fierce competition from UKIP as they target people who voted for Brexit and the tradtional Labour working classes Getty Images 1 of 9 UKIP leader and candidate Paul Nuttall leaves the polling station after voting in the Stoke Central by-election 
The harsh weather conditions meant that turnout was expected to be low with both results expected to be “on a knife edge” in what were previously two safe Labour seats. Whatever happens we have given Labour a tough battle in their own heartland Senior source 
And Labour sources have said that the by-elections “have left question marks” over how long Mr Corbyn can carry on as leader after fighting two tough battles to keep hold of seats in heartland territories. 
In Stoke Ukip leader Paul Nuttall was still optimistic as polls closed last night. 
A senior source said that voters who had pledged to back Ukip had said they would brave the fierce weather to vote. GETTY Tristram Hunt, once thought to be a future leader, left to become director of the V&A Museum 
He said: “Whatever happens we have given Labour a tough battle in their own heartland and it has been on a knife edge.” 
But Mr Nuttall’s hopes of easily winning the seat against a Labour candidate Gareth Snell, who described Brexit as “sh**” in a constituency which voted almost 70 per cent for Leave, have been hit by what he describes as a “smear campaign” against him. 
Mr Nuttall has been forced to spend much of his time denying accusations that he lied about being at the Hillsborough disaster in 1989 which led to the deaths of 96 Liverpool fans. 
Meanwhile the Tories handed out free umbrellas to voters to help brave the weather and were optimistic about winning Copeland as polls closed last night. GETTY Ukip leader Paul Nuttall was still optimistic as polls closed last night 
A win would be the first time since 1982 when a governing party took a seat off the main Opposition party in a by-election. 
It would be the first time since 1878 when the governing party had won in a contest with the main Opposition party outside a war and without a defection to another party. 
Labour was also trying to hold off another unwanted record of being the first Opposition party to lose two by-elections on the same day since 1854. 
The party focussed on claims that the NHS is under threat while the Tories highlighted Mr Corbyn’s opposition to nuclear energy in a Copeland where the industry is the main employer. 
Meanwhile, in Stoke Ukip focussed on immigration and the need to ensure that Brexit is delivered fully by the Government. Related articles
